awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Computational Algebraic Methods for Systems of Partial Difference-Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Natural processes, like the formation of a snowflake, can reveal deep connections between physical laws, which are often modeled as systems of mathematical equations, and symmetries, which can be captured mathematically as group actions.   In computer algebra software, which can help solve systems of equations, it would be good to be able to ensure that operations respect group actions and preserve symmetries.   Despite the over sixty-year history of algorithmic approaches in differential and difference algebra, there are currently no efficient computational techniques to analyze systems of algebraic partial difference-differential equations (PDDEs) and more general systems of partial differential equations (PDEs) with group action. This project aims to develop the theory and algorithms to determine the structure of solutions of a system of PDDEs or PDEs with additional conditions imposed by the action of transformation groups (e. g., PDEs with symmetries), for describing physical, chemical, or biological processes with symmetries.  The educational goal of the project is to involve into an interdepartmental program on applications of symbolic computation the PI will develop, not only undergraduate majors in computer science, mathematics, and physics at the Catholic University of America (CUA), but also engineering majors in the field of automatic control and biology majors who work with continuous and discrete mathematical models of biology systems. 

The key research directions of this project are: (1) Development of computational methods and algorithms for difference-differential elimination and for decomposition of solution sets of systems of algebraic PDDEs and PDEs with group action into unions of characterizable (?simple??) components. Extension of these techniques to systems with weighted basic operators. (2) Elaboration of methods and algorithms for the evaluation of dimension characteristics of the solution sets of the above-mentioned systems. In particular, the PI will obtain algorithms for computing dimension polynomials and quasi-polynomials that express the Einstein?s strength of a system of PDDEs.  (3) Application of the developed techniques to systems of PDDEs and PDEs with group action that arise in physics, automatic control, chemistry and biology.  
The main methods and approaches of the project include the characteristic set technique for difference-differential polynomials and its generalizations to the cases of several term orderings and weighted basic operators, the relative Groebner basis method, the techniques of dimension polynomials and quasi-polynomials, and decomposition methods for algebraic PDDEs and PDEs with group action.  The results will be demonstrated in interdisciplinary research projects at CUA.

por.por_cntn:
Differential, difference and difference-differential equations constitute main tools that scientists and engineers use to make mathematical models of real life phenomena. Whereas continuous-time and discrete-time processes depending on several factors are described by systems of partial differential and difference equations, respectively, processes that include both continuous and discrete components  (such as processes with time delay) are governed by systems of partial difference-differential equations (PDDEs).  Furthermore, very often characteristics of the considered processes have certain symmetries, which can be captured mathematically as group actions.  In this connection, the development of computational methods and algorithms for the description of solution sets of systems of PDDEs and such systems with group action is of primary importance in applications.

This project has developed new computational algebraic techniques and algorithms for the analysis of systems of PDDEs and associated algebraic structures. The main project outcomes that address the intellectual merit are as follows.       

(1) Development of computational methods of generalized characteristic sets and relative Groebner bases for several rankings of variables induced by actions of several sets of derivations and translations. Implementation of the obtained algorithms in PYTHON and MAPLE and their application to computing dimension polynomials of systems of algebraic PDDEs. These polynomials express Einstein?s strength of such a system, a characteristic that describes the size of the solution set and allows one to choose an optimal system of PDDEs for the description of a physical phenomenon.  

(2) Extension of the techniques of generalized characteristic sets and relative Groebner bases to PDDEs with group action and/or weighted derivations and translations (the latter are PDDEs that describe physical processes with different degrees of dependence on the involved parameters).  

(3)  Obtaining a method for comparison analysis of systems of PDDEs (in particular for difference schemes for their numerical solutions) via their Einstein?s strength. Evaluation of this characteristic for difference schemes for Murray, Fisher, Burgers and some other reaction-diffusion partial differential equations (PDEs), as well as for several fundamental systems of PDEs of mathematical physics.

The broader impacts of the project are as follows.

(1) The project has essentially contributed to the analysis of systems of partial differential, difference, and difference-differential equations that are in the core of mathematical models in physics, engineering, chemistry, and biology. The obtained results have many applications to the qualitative analysis of fundamental systems of equations of mathematical physics (such as various forms of Maxwell equations, Dirac equations, etc.), automatic control, chemical and biological mathematical models. They also give a powerful tool for the comparative analysis of systems of PDDEs with group action and/or weighted basic operators that describe the same physical (or chemical, biological, etc.) process. This analysis is very important for choosing optimal systems of PDDEs that describe mathematical models in applications.

(2) The project activities have produced methods for computing dimensional characteristics (in particular, Einstein?s strength) of systems of PDDEs whose solutions should be invariant with respect to a certain group action. Systems with this additional condition play key roles in mathematical models in applications (in the models where solutions should be invariant with respect to certain coordinate transformations).

(3) On the educational side, the project has provided new opportunities for The Catholic University of America students who major in mathematics, computer science, physics, engineering, chemistry and biology. A new undergraduate course ?Applications of Computer Algebra? and a new graduate course ?Computational Differential and Difference Algebra? whose programs has been developed in the frame of the project, are aimed at the study of fundamental concepts and basic techniques of computer algebra and at incorporating these techniques into students' research. (The graduate course was taught to master?s students after the department opened its Master?s Program in 2019.)  Some parts of the developed programs will be included into the courses ?Mathematical Physics?, ?Discrete Structures?, and ?Research Topics in Biology?. This activity will improve performance and skills of the involved students; it will also result in developing and disseminating new educational materials that have been and will be created in connection with the programs. In the course of his work on the project, the PI mentored seven undergraduate students in computer algebra techniques; four of these students continued their studies in the frame of Master and PhD programs.  

(4) The main results were disseminated through nine refereed publications and twenty-four presentations at International conferences, seminars and colloquiums.
